The third, the five chapters below ten kinds of habitual tendencies, clarify the practices in the third ground.
It is divided into two parts:
The first two chapters clarify the practices that give rise to disgust, and the latter three chapters are the practices that are disgusted with.
The former is divided into two:
This chapter clarifies the formation of habitual tendencies, and the latter chapter increases and takes them in.

The first, because this ground subdues afflictions with disgust, it accumulates and forms habitual tendencies in various practices, and only then can it ultimately cut off and subdue afflictions, thus called habitual tendencies.

Among the ten, the first is the fundamental habitual tendency of practice, the second is the habitual tendency of accomplishing practice, the third is teaching those of lower capacities, the fourth is seeing those of higher capacities, the fifth is taking rebirth, the sixth is great practices, the seventh is great vows, the eighth is the ten perfections, the ninth is the wisdom of principle, and the tenth is the wisdom of phenomena.

Second, the ten kinds of grasping clarify the grasping of increase and flourishing. The Jin edition calls it blazing, because by accumulating and delighting in the previous [stages], one attains growth.
The second, ten kinds of cultivation and below, the next three sections clarify the practices of aversion that are aroused.
It is divided into three:
This section directly clarifies cultivation. The first eight cultivate causes, the last two cultivate results;
The second, accomplishing the Buddha Dharma, clarifies the excellent conditions for cultivation, because one can accomplish them by relying on these ten;
The third, ten kinds of retrogression, clarifies the avoidance of faults in cultivation, specifically raising ten faults and generally enjoining one to stay far away from them.
The text is all understandable.
The fourth, path of separation from birth and below, the next five sections clarify the practices in the fourth ground.
It is divided into three:

The first, this section clarifies the causes of increasing and growing in the practice of pure counteraction; the next section clarifies its purity; the last three sections clarify the increasing and growing in counteraction and practice.
First, the first three grounds are likened to raw food in the belly, with views and other delusions still present.

The fourth ground is likened to the supramundane, with pure antidotes able to eliminate them, referring to being free from conditioned activities, attaining non-arising, manifesting pure and mature practice free from coarseness, as extensively explained in the Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra.
Now, this is the cause for that pure antidote, thus it is called the path.
The Stages of the Bodhisattva Sutra has ten Dharma illumination gates, the first being observing sentient beings. Now, only this one phrase is elaborated, the rest are omitted.
The conclusion states not mixed with the two vehicles because by cultivating the ten phrases of dual practice, it is different from the two vehicles' path of seeing and being free from birth.
Second, the definitive Dharma clarifies its purity.
Above it clarifies being able to eliminate, now it reveals what is attained, because it can attain the supramundane definitive Dharma.
Therefore, that text says attaining that internal Dharma, being born in the TathÄgata family.
Among the ten, the first five are one's own benefits, and the latter five are benefiting others.
The third, from giving rise to the Buddha's teachings below, has three gates, clarifying the increase of counteracting practice.
Within that, it is divided into two parts:
First, two gates clarify the increase of practice, and the latter one gate clarifies the counteracting of practice.
Now, at the beginning, there are also two:
This gate correctly clarifies the increase, and the latter gate reveals the establishment of the superior name.
Now, at the beginning, giving rise from conditions is the meaning of increase, also like exhalation increasing its abundance.

Among the ten, the first two are in accord with people's faith in the Dharma, the next two are the non-falseness of vows and wisdom, the next two are the vastness of time and place, the next two are the uninterrupted pervasiveness, and the last two are the superior practices that embrace beings.
Second, the name of the hero, which is the establishment of the superior name, is due to the internal increase of virtuous practices, and therefore the excellent name is established externally.
Among the ten, the first four are named from the object, the fifth and sixth are named according to the essence, the above are all one's own benefits;
The seventh and eighth are for benefiting others, and the ninth is for manifesting supremacy, because they possess both kinds of benefits. The above are all called causes of self-benefit;
The last one is the fruit of superior progress. All the above are provisional names based on virtue.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra, fascicle forty-six, explains that the provisional names based on virtue for bodhisattvas are of sixteen kinds. The first is called bodhisattva, and the sixteenth is called Dharma master.
The eighth fascicle of the Abhidharmasamuccaya and the twelfth fascicle of the Ornament of the MahÄyÄna SÅ«tras both explain it in the same way.
Moreover, the SÅ«tra of the Heavenly Prince Åšreá¹£á¹­hin establishes the name with five meanings, but fearing it would be too much, I will not discuss it here.
Second, there are ten kinds of paths, clarifying the practice of counteracting.
The Sutra on the Stages provisionally uses the stages to extensively clarify the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment;
Now, because it is based on the actual stages, it increases the number to show that the ten are all for counteracting and are all the correct path.

Among the ten, the first two, the last one, the name and meaning are all not shared. The three paths have both name and meaning in common. The four paths up to the ninth have the same name as the HÄ«nayÄna, but the meaning is only in the true teaching.
The first three are understandable.
As for the meaning of reality, the four practices say: Skillfully dedicating without rest.

The five roots are the root of concentration, knowing the entry and exit of samÄdhi. The six supernormal powers are seeing death and rebirth with the heavenly eye. The seven are accomplished with the six recollections, and adding the recollection of sentient beings is for great compassion, which is also one recollection among the seven expanded factors of enlightenment.
The rest can be understood by analogy.
The eight right thoughts accord with omniscience.
The nine successive concentrations all have both tranquility and function.
The first concentration is free from desire, anger, and harm, but transforms sentient beings in reverse, also using desire, etc., to speak, therefore it is said to be all verbal actions.
Although the second concentration is without initial and sustained thought, the pure thought without destruction is used as the cause of speech.
The third concentration is free from joy, but gives rise to the joy of the Dharma.
The fourth concentration is free from bliss, but experiences the bliss of the path of liberation.
From this is not below, it clarifies the four formless concentrations, but generally shows the superiority.

Although abiding in cessation refers to the attainment of cessation. Although this attainment completely ceases all non-perpetually active mental factors and mental functions, and also ceases the defiled portion of the perpetually active [mental factors and mental functions], it is still called the attainment of the cessation of conceptualization and sensation because it is preceded by the aversion to conceptualization and sensation. This is because the stage of non-conceptualization still has subtle conceptualization, which is the sensation of equanimity.
Now, in the true teaching, it is clarified that the nature of sensation and so forth is extinguished, and therefore it does not cease the practice of bodhisattvas.
Therefore, the seventh ground says that one can enter [the attainment of cessation] moment by moment, and also arise from it moment by moment, and so forth.
The rest is explained in the third ground and the seventh ground.
Among the ten powers, the first six, beginning with pervading all, are the knowledge of the path that leads everywhere. The eighth is the divine eye, and the ninth is the knowledge of past lives.
Now, one knows the three times completely, let alone one's past lives.
The rest is explained in the first assembly.
The fifth, the two gates below immeasurable paths, clarify the practices in the fifth ground.
It is divided into two:
This section clarifies the practice of the superior antidotes to pride, while the following section clarifies the practice within the latter two divisions.
Now, the first part is divided into two:

First, four approaches are generally indicated, because these four approaches equally reveal the meaning of the Way, and the meaning is all immeasurable. They are classified together, so they are generally indicated.
Since they must be distinguished according to the meaning, the latter two are included in the following.

Second, from Buddha's disciple below, the first approach is specifically clarified, namely the ten minds of equality and the practice in accordance with the Way, because they are all the path traversed by the bodhisattva's correct Way.
Since all phenomena encountered are suchness, the Way is omnipresent. How much more so are the eleven such as space each immeasurable, and how could the Way have limits?
Among the ten, the first four each have one immeasurability, while the latter four all have the Buddha realm as the immeasurability.
Language is also related to sentient beings, and it is also the realm of taming.
Immeasurable eons are discussed vertically as immeasurable, while the remaining seven are discussed horizontally as immeasurable.
Space is both horizontal and vertical, while the Dharma realm is neither horizontal nor vertical.
As for the Dharma realm of space, it is in terms of having no divisions. The other eight are both vast and numerous, and also have no divisions.
Second, immeasurable auxiliary paths refer to the superior practice of the path of non-abiding, as well as the superior practice within the superior fruition.
Using wisdom to accord with suchness is called the correct path. The myriad practices and supportive conditions are all auxiliary paths.
The combined practice of these two is called the path of non-abiding.

Now, the cultivation of perfect interfusion is such that there is nothing that does not accord with suchness, and all are the correct path. They mutually support each other and are all auxiliary paths. Therefore, the ten such as space are no different from the previous chapter.

However, the correct path does not follow along with events and is therefore called immeasurable. The auxiliary path follows along with events and is therefore called boundless, inexhaustible, and so forth, according to the events it follows along with.
The single chapter on the immeasurable cultivation of the path in the sixth ground clarifies the practices within the sixth ground.
Because prajÃ±Ä manifests and is true cultivation.
Without going, coming, and so forth, it is the ten equalities and so forth.
Among the ten, the first four are the practices within the superior counteraction to conceit, which encompass the ten equalities;
The latter six are the superior practice within the superior fruition of that, the superior practice of the path of non-abiding.
The ten kinds of contemplating conditions have been extensively explained there, so they are not briefly explained here.
Among the four, the first three are about the Dharma, and the last one is about a metaphor.
Among the Dharma, they are opened up from different meanings to form the previous eight, and now they are generally explained.

The first is not giving rise to the mind, the second accords with the fundamental nature, and the third eliminates the characteristics of cultivation. It can also be matched with the three natures and the three kinds of non-nature. Contemplate it according to the principles;
The fourth raises seven metaphors to generally illustrate non-attachment.
Among the latter six, the fifth is although realizing the three kinds of emptiness, still accumulating merit and virtue.
The sixth is not attached to the inexpressible Dharma of the teachings. The principle is perfect, but the words are biased. Words cannot express it.
The one without words is because the nature is without words.
The one apart from words is because only by forgetting words can one accord with it.

The seventh does not destroy the Dharma realm of phenomena, the eighth does not destroy the principle of true suchness, and the ninth generally clarifies the wisdom of provisional and real, so the power is inexhaustible. The above are all the cultivation of one's own part;
Tenth, it is the cultivation of surpassing progress.
The seventh, from adorn the path, has three gates, clarifying the practices in the seventh ground.
It is divided into three parts:
The first gate clarifies the dual practice of skillful means and truth, the next gate clarifies moment-to-moment progress, and the last gate clarifies the mastery of taking and bestowing.
Now, first, it is the ten kinds of skillful means wisdom and the practice of the fruits of dual practice in that ground, which counteracts the enjoyment of effortless practice.
Because skillful means and truth are mutually adorned, it is called adornment.
In the list, the first five are one's own practice without defilement;
The next four are according to existence to embrace and transform:
One, transforming without defilement; two, abiding in the correct entering the deviant; three, the skillful means of upholding and violating; four, the skillful means of people and dharmas;
Ten, generally manifesting the skillful means of cause and effect, within which there are three:
First, the cause is complete yet showing incompleteness, showing birth, because the cause is not yet full;
Next, from the same as the three times, below, the same as the realm of fruition yet not abandoning the cause.
The cause has ten phrases, the practice is common to the two benefits.

Dharma refers to the teachings, karma means benefiting others, path means right wisdom, rules refer to the proscriptions and permissions, taking means making vows, skillful means refers to provisional and real, the above are all the activities, speaking in general terms about the causes and essence.
The function of accomplishment refers to the great function accomplished by the causes.
The power of upholding refers to the long-lasting function that is uninterrupted.
The following why and below are the reasons and explanations, which can be understood.
Second, the full ten, clarifying the practice of advancing moment by moment.
This is the cultivation of immeasurable kinds within the antidotes to those hindrances, as well as the distinctions in the factors of enlightenment within the section on dual practice.
Among the ten, the first two are about practice, one is precepts and the other is diligence;
The next two are about spiritual powers, one is general and the other is specific;
The next two are about the mind, one is vows and the other is resolutions;ğŸ”½The next two are about the Dharma, one is following and the other is upholding;
The last two are about virtue, one is expounding and the other is subduing.
Third, the ten kinds of hands clarify the practice of freely taking and bestowing, which is the great meaning that can be accomplished within the section on dual practice.
Among the ten, the first one is about taking, meaning cultivating all Buddha Dharmas moment by moment, heading towards Buddha-wisdom.
The remaining nine are about bestowing. Among them, the first five clarify the four means of conversion: the first is giving;
the second is kind speech;
the third and fourth are both beneficial actions;
the fifth is the same hand of shared action, acting to pull out.
The last four are the four families:
the first is due to the purity of suffering, the second is due to revealing the truths, the third is due to the power of prajÃ±Ä, and the fourth is due to abandoning afflictions.
The eighth, the three sections below ten bellies, clarify the practices within the eighth ground.
Because of internally realizing non-arising, they all use internal matters to clarify the perfection of internal virtues.
It is divided into three parts:

The first gate clarifies the virtue of pure tolerance, which is the purity of the path of non-abiding in the section on the stage of accumulation, and because of attaining non-arising in the section on pure forbearance, and also because of being free from all attachments in the section on attaining superior practices.

The bellies of worldly people contain much impurity, but in these ten, the first six and the last one clarify that there is no evil that is not left behind, and the three of seven, eight, and nine clarify that there is no good that is not accumulated. If one can be like this, then the ordinary is the Buddha's belly.
Second, there are ten treasuries. The previous one generally raises the belly, and now the five internal organs are specifically clarified.
Because of attaining superior practices, the Buddhas encourage the arising of immeasurable virtues that are born in a single thought and contain and mature them.
Among the ten, the first three give rise to the Three Jewels;
The next three mature the three groups. Even those of wrong determination have Buddha-nature, because it is the cause for the future.

Arousing compassion as the condition, the Nirvana Sutra says, Even though icchantikas have severed wholesome roots, by the power of buddha-nature, wholesome roots will still be able to grow in the future.
This is the meaning of that.
The last four are the bestowal of the Buddha's fruition.
The last is the state of omniscience.

Third, there are ten mental states, which are one of the five viscera, the most excellent, and the master of the five viscera. This ground can accomplish the effortless mental state of all wholesome activities.
In the first ground, the mental state is explained. The Sanskrit term citta refers to the mind of thought and cognition, in contrast to body and speech.
Now, the Sanskrit term há¹›daya means the flesh and blood heart, in contrast to the other viscera.
Among the ten, the first six are for one's own benefit. Among them, the first two are wholesome activities, one diligent, one vigorous;
The next two destroy evil, one destroying conditions, one destroying causes;
The next two accomplish practices, one firm, one pure;
The next two are the mind of embracing sentient beings: first, using wisdom to enlighten them, and second, using compassion to rescue them.
The abode of great Brahma refers to the four immeasurable [minds].
The last two are the accomplishments: first, profound, and second, firm.
The ninth has two gates below armor, which clarify the practices of the ninth ground bodhisattva entering into existence, being fully equipped with external adornments.
The first gate clarifies the ten minds of entering the ground, like wearing armor to defend internally, as one is about to enter.
The ten phrases can be understood.
Second, the ten weapons.
Weapons break through the external, as the mind abiding on the ground exhausts the ten afflictions, and there is nothing that is not broken through.
Among the ten, the first five are weapons that follow along to break through hindrances;
The next three are weapons that oppose to break through hindrances, like using thieves to break through thieves;
The next one is a weapon that is neither following along nor opposing, like using good strategies without using weapons, as there is nothing that is not broken through;
The last is the weapon of accomplishing all virtues.

The tenth section on the ten kinds of heads and below the next thirteen sections clarify the practices of the ten grounds. Since the virtues of the ten grounds are perfect, they are entrusted to the four activities of the six sense faculties to clarify them.
They are roughly divided into three parts:
The first is a general statement on the head of virtues, the next six are the superior virtues of the six sense faculties, and the last six are the established norms of the four activities.
Now, at the beginning, one abides in the position of receiving the official rank, and the head emerges from among the many sages.
Among the ten, the first three are the heads of fruition;
The next three are marked by causes and explained by fruition;
The last four directly clarify the head of practice.
The second section on the ten eyes and below the next six sections clarify the six sense faculties, which are divided into six parts:
The first clarifies the ten eyes, which is because of truly knowing and seeing all dharmas in the section on the end of greatness.
Among the ten, the first five have the same names as in the various teachings, but their essence and function are different from the various schools. The flesh eye sees forms within obstructions.

The Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom, chapter 37, says the flesh eye sees near but not far, sees in front but not behind, etc., while the heavenly eye can see far, etc., but still has limitations.
Now the flesh eye sees all forms, surpassing the other two eyes.
Chapter 44 points out that the inconceivable sÅ«tras should see far, but this is not mentioned here.
However, the heavenly eye is a provisional combination, and does not see the true nature.
Now, clarifying seeing the mind, it seems the same as that.
However, the mind is both nature and characteristics, so it is also not the same.
Here, the wisdom eye is similar to their Dharma eye, and here the Dharma eye is similar to their wisdom eye.
The reason for the mutual similarity is that their wisdom eye cannot see sentient beings, cannot extinguish the same and different, and cannot liberate beings;
Now, revealing the true surpasses the provisional, and clarifies the ability in reverse.
In their Dharma eye, although it knows the Dharma, it cannot universally know the expedient path of sentient beings;
Now, since this is the opposite, it is clear that all intentions are different from the provisional.
That Buddha's eye is subtle and knows everything;
Now, citing the superior to illustrate the inferior, and the ten powers are all-encompassing.

Among the last five, the eye of wisdom sees phenomena, which is the same as the eye of light that opens out from the Dharma eye. The meaning of the body of wisdom and light encompasses the Dharma and wisdom.
The eye of leaving birth and death: Nirvana cannot be seen, only by transcending seeing can one see it. Because one sees perfect quiescence.
The unobstructed eye: It comprehensively sees the realms of all eyes, all without obstruction. This is one eye endowed with many.
In order to preserve the distinct characteristics, the ten eyes must be listed.

The eye of omniscience is precisely the universal eye. Not only does it see the manifold Dharma realm, but also the Dharma realm is precisely the eye. Because it is the universal gate, it is known that the ten eyes are entirely the unobstructed Dharma realm as their essence.

If distinguishing the sequence, the flesh eye sees the suffering of birth, next the heavenly eye understands their minds, next distinguishing the faculties and objects, next introducing them to reality, next causing them to attain the Buddha's power, next following the light to see, next equally returning to quiescence, and finally equally the same as the Dharma realm.
The rest is as explained in other chapters.

Second, the ten ears: The six sense faculties such as the eyes, by attaining the unsurpassed liberation and spiritual powers, all see, hear, smell, touch, etc. freely, therefore they are generally distinguished by action.
This approach also explains the section on the name, because it hears and upholds the TathÄgata's great Dharma rain.

The first two avoid conformity and opposition, the next two abandon the small and delight in the great, the next two pity suffering and detest pleasure, the next two fulfill the fruit and perfect the cause, and the last two understand the conventional as the same as the true, with compassion and wisdom operating together.
Third, there are ten noses, because they smell and practice fragrances.
Among them, the first four smell the essence of fragrances. The Abhidharma-koÅ›a has four, which are collectively called fragrances:
The first is good smell, such as frankincense and so on;
the second is bad smell, such as onions and so on;
the third is equal smell;

the fourth is unequal smell, which refers to the smell that benefits the body, called equal smell, and the smell that harms the body, called unequal smell, so it is also not separate from good and bad.

Now, in this case, both are smelled. Smelling the upper two has no separate substance. It is neither fragrant nor foul, forming three in contrast to the previous. It is like firewood and charcoal, and so on.

Next, the three smells of fragrance express their function. In the YogÄcÄra and other texts, since the two realms above have neither the nose nor tongue consciousness, they also have neither the smell nor taste objects. Speaking of their absence of coarseness,
this smell of the peak of existence is clear in its smell of subtlety, due to the power of the bodhisattva.

Moreover, the word peak is often used in other places to refer to the ultimate form. According to the Jin text, smelling the fragrance of the non-conceptual realm, the word peak also refers to the peak of the three existences. Since there is the form of the spiritual fruit, there is also the fragrance of the spiritual fruit.
The last three hear the teachings of supramundane people.
Fourth, having ten tongues, in order to expound the flavor of the Dharma.
The last three are to perfect the six sense faculties, not to manifest the three karmas, because the three karmas already existed before.
Among the ten, the first five manifest virtues by means of eloquence, and the last five are about functions.
Ten, subduing the four demons. The demon is the celestial demon, and birth is the demon of the aggregates.
Fifth, having ten bodies, because the body is formed according to practice.
Sixth, having ten intentions. The first is general, and the remaining nine are specific. The text is all understandable.
Third, the six gates clarify the practice of the four deportments.
First, a practitioner, because the Dharma of wandering is moving.
Among them, causing to turn back means turning contaminated samÄdhi back to uncontaminated.
Not cutting off birth and death means that if cut off, it is not true nirvÄá¹‡a.
The rest can be understood.
Second, the ten kinds of abiding are because of stopping scattered agitation.
The first seven are one's own abiding, and the last three are superior progress abiding.
Third, sitting means to be seated for a long time, the first four worldly sittings are to attract beings, and the last six Dharma sittings are to accomplish virtue.
Fourth, the ten recline means to let go of body and mind and conform to the essence of dharmas.
Among the ten, the first three manifest samÄdhi: one is the preparatory practice of regulating body and mind, two is cultivation, and three is attaining samÄdhi;
The remaining seven are the benefits of samÄdhi, which also include other wholesome dharmas.
However, each of the ten matters is the same as the meaning of reclining:

The first three and the last two can be known. Four is because one reclines alone. Five is because one is free from lying on one's back. Six is because one is free from leaning. Seven is because one contemplates the bright appearance and mutually arouses alertness. Eight is because one reclines on the right side.
Fifth, the abodes means that wisdom has a place to rest.
The previous clarifies the one who abides, this distinguishes the abided upon, the ten phrases can be known.
Sixth, the places of practice, the previous distinguishes the one who practices, this clarifies the practiced upon.
Among them, the first four are one's own practice. The first is based on the four mindfulnesses. Ä€nanda had four questions, and the Buddha told him to rely on them.
Now explaining the reliance on practice, the rest can be understood by analogy.
The practices of the ten grounds are finished.
The sixth major section, from ten observations below, answers the question of the perfection of the cause and fruition with fifty-one topics.

If discussing it in terms of the actual, the four topics from accomplishing the powers of the TathÄgata below clarify the perfection of the fruition, while the previous ones are the perfection of the cause, because the first five of the eight appearances still belong to the cause, in order to clarify that the eight appearances are all manifestations.
In general, entering the fruition is divided into two parts:
The first thirty-two topics clarify the ultimate perfection of the cause, which is the stage of equal enlightenment;
The latter nineteen topics from ten kinds of abiding in Tuá¹£ita Heaven below clarify the perfect practice of the manifest fruition, which is the stage of wondrous enlightenment.
In the former, it is divided into three parts:
The first fourteen topics clarify the essence of the causal practices;
The second section, from ten kinds of meanings, has eight chapters, explaining skillful means and practice;
The third section, from ten kinds of demons, has ten chapters, explaining the causes and practices for eliminating hindrances.
In the first section, there are two parts:
The first four chapters are skillful means for generating practices, and the second ten chapters are the essence of the ten perfections.
In the first part, there are three:
The first two chapters are mental activities of observation, the next one chapter is physical activities of mastery, and the last one chapter is verbal activities of proclamation.
In the first part, the first chapter on observation is because it understands skillful means and penetrates through blockages.
In it, the first two chapters observe what is to be transformed;
The next four chapters observe the Dharma that transforms, namely principle, fruition, teaching, and practice;
The last three chapters observe the stages, first surpassing inferiority, second attaining the stage, and third the same fruition and function.
The second chapter on universal observation is because the deliberation is all-encompassing.
The first six chapters use the six perfections to treat the six kinds of sentient beings' obstructions;
The last four chapters clearly show the two kinds of benefits, namely following people to realize the Dharma, and transforming those below to accomplish those above.
Second, in the mastery of physical actions, it means that real virtues are internally fulfilled and majestic virtues overflow externally, like the majestic power of a lion king.
There is another interpretation, as explained in the Chapter on the Dharma Realm.
Among them, the first five are analogies, and the next four are about the Dharma.
The above are all one's own stage, and the last one is the stage of superior progress.
Third, the lion's roar means that since one is brave and fearless, one can proclaim with certainty.
Among the two, it causes beings to transcend suffering and escape the cause of suffering, and to peacefully realize cessation. Therefore.
The rest can be understood. The following fifty-eight scrolls.
The second, from the ten kinds of giving below, ten chapters clarify its practice essence.
Among them, it first clarifies the six pÄramitÄs, and then reveals the four immeasurables.
The meaning of the ten pÄramitÄs has already been explained above.
All say pure because they are free from obscurations and hindrances, and are not the same as the giving, precepts, etc. in the world.
However, they are all based on the ten perfections, each serving a single meaning, with different combinations of the nine and three types of giving.
If I were to explain them in detail, I fear it would be too verbose, so I will explain them directly according to their significance.
Now, the first ten types of giving: 1. Giving without partiality, which is a specific meaning within pure giving;
2. Giving that fulfills wishes;

3. Giving that brings happiness in both this and future lives, in the Sanskrit text called timely and rescuing from difficulty, because it does not lose its benefits. The remaining seven are all universal giving;
4. Namely, observing what is appropriate and inappropriate, what is harmful and not suitable, etc., giving first to the extremely poor and lowly, etc.;
5. Not hoping for karmic retribution, also pure giving;
6. Also difficult giving, because one has no attachment to cherished possessions;
7. Because one has nothing internal or external that one does not give up;
8-10. All are skillful giving.
This skillful dedication treats two faults:
1. Observing that the nature of all conditioned things is not solid, treating the superior merit seen in future results;
Second, by possessing great compassion, one treats the two vehicles who seek to realize the unconditioned, thus practicing the path of non-abiding and heading towards enlightenment.
Ninth is the giving that benefits beings, always giving them wealth and the Dharma, thus it is called not abandoning.
Tenth is the perfection of forgetting characteristics.
However, these ten perfections all have the three wheels, but the meaning has slight differences, as explained in the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra.
These above ten kinds of giving all pervade the three kinds of giving.
Second, the ten precepts: the first three are precepts, the seventh gathers beings, and the rest all gather goodness;
Moreover, the fourth is the precept of vastness, the fifth is the precept of dedication, the above two are all kinds of precepts;
Sixth, because of upholding the subtle, it is the precept of difficulty;
Seventh, causing others to repent and eliminate, it is the precept of the good person;
Eighth, the precept that is included in the completeness of rules and observances, because all evils cease and good conduct arises;
Ninth, the precept of permanent liberation, the above two are the precept of purity;
Tenth, the precept of causing others to attain happiness in the two worlds.
Third, the ten forbearances: the first three are the forbearance of enduring harm from others, enduring the three karmas of others that harm oneself;

The next three are the forbearance of enduring suffering, enduring what is unpleasant in the beginning, middle, and end, enduring physical suffering to benefit others, and the two later [forbearances] are the forbearance of contemplating the Dharma.
